pageData.text: This investigation examines the internal and external anatomy of a crayfish. Students will identify adaptations of the crustacean that make it suited to its habitat and its role within that habitat.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1A: External Anatomy and Appendages - 45 minutes
Activity 1B: Internal Anatomy - 45 minutes
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1A: External Anatomy and Appendages - 45 minutes
Activity 1B: Internal Anatomy - 45 minutes

pageData.text: Throughout this manual are numbers that appear in parentheses, e.g., (2). These numbers correspond to numbers on the labeled dissection mat located in your kit.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Camera or cell phone capable of taking photographs
70% isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) or other non-bleach disinfectant
Identify internal and external features of a crayfish.
Define characteristics that crayfish share with other arthropods.
Define the role of a crayfish in its environment.
Relate anatomical structures to their functions.

pageData.text: Cray fish are decapods, with four sets of walking legs and a large set of claws in front. However, it is not uncommon to see a crayfish with only nine limbs, or with one limb that is much smaller than the others.  This is because crayfish have the ability to voluntarily amputate their limbs. They may do this as a predator escape mechanism or if their limb is damaged in one of their frequent fights with other crayfish. And unlike humans, crayfish can regrow amputated limbs. The new limbs start out small but can eventually grow back to full size as the crayfish molts. Not only is this ability important for the crayfish’s survival, but it can also provide insight into how human tissues could be regenerated. Scientists are currently working out the exact molecular signaling pathways involved in this process to determine whether the same mechanisms could be used in humans to recover from injuries<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>.

1Feleke, M., Bennett, S., Chen, J., Chandler, D., Hu, X., & Xu, J. (2021). Biological insights into the rapid tissue regeneration of freshwater crayfish and crustaceans. Cell biochemistry and function, 39(6), 740–753. https://doi.org/10.1002/cbf.3653.

pageData.altText: A freshwater crayfish with 9 legs.

pageData.text: Crayfish, also called crawfish and crawdads, are crustaceans that are similar to lobsters, shrimp, and crabs. Crayfish belong to the phylum Arthropoda (Table 1) together with insects and spiders. Organisms of this phylum display <button class='glossary-text'>segmentation</button>, where the body is composed of repeated units (segments). These segments can be specialized for particular functions. The presence of segmentation led biologists in the past to consider arthropods and annelids (segmented worms) as closely related phyla. More recently, however, molecular evidence has suggested that segmentation arose separately in the two phyla and they are not as closely related as previously thought. The majority of crustaceans are aquatic, with a few notable exceptions such as woodlice, also known as pill bugs, and a few species of crabs. Similar to crabs, crayfish are decapods, which means having 10 legs. Most decapods, including crayfish, have four pairs of walking legs (31) and one pair of legs that are heavily modified into large claws called <button class='glossary-text'>chelipeds</button> (9). There are two major groups of crayfish: the Astacoidea, which are found in the northern hemisphere and the Parastacoidea that are located in the southern hemisphere. These groups were originally defined by geography but are well supported by molecular phylogenies. However, divisions at the family level and below remain problematic.

tableData.text: Also includes spiders, centipedes, and insects
Also includes krill and pill bugs
Also includes shrimp, lobster, and crabs

pageData.text: Like all arthropods, crayfish possess a hard external skeleton called an <button class='glossary-text'>exoskeleton</button> (11), which is made of chitin. Unlike most other arthropods, which have three major divisions in their body structure (head, thorax, and abdomen [1]), decapods are characterized by a fusion of the first two regions into a <button class='glossary-text'>cephalothorax</button> (8) (Figure 1). The <button class='glossary-text'>dorsal</button> side (see Table 2 for definitions of directional terms) of the cephalothorax is covered by a hard shell called a <button class='glossary-text'>carapace</button> (7). The location where the head and thorax are fused can be identified by the presence of the cervical groove. The carapace extends to a point at the <button class='glossary-text'>anterior</button> end called a <button class='glossary-text'>rostrum</button> (25), which helps protect the eyes (12). While <button class='glossary-text'>segmentation</button> of the body is obscured on the dorsal side by the carapace, the <button class='glossary-text'>ventral</button> side of the crayfish reveals the segments, each with associated paired appendages. The first pair of appendages are the antennules (5) followed by the longer antennae (4). The next six segments are fused around the mouth, which is made up of six pairs of appendages: one pair of mandibles (20), two pairs of maxillae (22), and three pairs of maxillipeds (23). The next segment bears the first of five pairs of walking legs. The first pair, the <button class='glossary-text'>chelipeds</button>, end in a large claw, in which the crayfish uses primarily for defense.

The next two pairs of legs have small pincers on them, whereas the fourth and fifth have none. On the abdomen are located five pairs of legs called swimmerets (28). In males, the first and second pairs are slightly larger and are angled forward. In females, the first pair is rudimentary and the remaining swimmerets are longer than those of the male. At the <button class='glossary-text'>posterior</button> end of the crayfish are two pairs of flipper-like uropods (30) and the telson (29), which is not considered to be a segment.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Figure labeling key external features of the crayfish

pageData.question: Crayfish belong to which phylum, along with insects and spiders?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Crayfish belong to the phylum Arthropoda, subphylum Crustacea.

pageData.question: How many legs do decapods, such as crayfish, have?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Similar to crabs, crayfish are decapods, which means having 10 legs.

pageData.text: Crayfish color varies by species and diet; many are a reddish-brown color, but others are bright blue or green. Like many other cave-dwelling organisms, crayfish species that have evolved in underground lakes and rivers have lost almost all of their pigmentation.

pageData.subTitle: Movement
pageData.text: Crayfish are <button class='glossary-text'>benthic</button> organisms, which mean they live on the bottom of fresh water systems. They walk along the bottom substrate with the majority of their weight on their fourth and fifth pairs of walking legs. Their tail can be folded up under their body and used to propel them backwards rapidly if startled, but they cannot truly swim. The abdominal legs are called swimmerets but their purpose is primarily to create a current that facilitates respiration.

pageData.subTitle: Respiration and Circulation
pageData.text: The swimmerets create water currents along the abdomen. The water enters the fill chamber at the base of the legs and at the <button class='glossary-text'>posterior</button> end of the <button class='glossary-text'>carapace</button>. The segment of the leg closest to the body (the <button class='glossary-text'>coxae</button>) has stiff hairs, called <button class='glossary-text'>setae</button>, which filter water before it gets to the gills (15). Attached the posterior two pairs of maxillae, are the <button class='glossary-text'>scaphognathites</button>, or <button class='glossary-text'>gill bailers</button>, which help to pull water out of the gill chamber (14). The gill chamber is formed by a portion of the carapace called the <button class='glossary-text'>branchiostegite</button> on one side and by the body wall on the other. The exact number of gills varies with species. Crayfish generally have gills arising at the base of the second and third pairs of maxillipeds, and at the base of each of the five pairs of walking legs. These gills are called <button class='glossary-text'>podobranchs</button> (pod = Greek for foot). <button class='glossary-text'>Arthrobranchs</button> (arthro = Greek for joint) have their gill origin above and closer to the center of the body than the podobranchs. Some crayfish have rudimentary <button class='glossary-text'>pleurobranchs</button> (pleuro = Greek for side), which arise interior to the arthrobranchs and higher on the body wall.

Each gill has two vessels running in opposite directions along a central axis. Through these vessels runs hemolymph that is similar in function to blood in vertebrates. Hemolymph does not rely on hemoglobin to bind oxygen but rather a compound called hemocyanin, which is blue when oxygenated instead of red. Filamentous branches of the gills are arranged around this central axis. Each filament is divided in half by a septum running from the base to almost out to the tip. Water flows in the same direction as the incoming (<button class='glossary-text'>afferent</button>) hemolymph but counter to the larger outgoing (<button class='glossary-text'>efferent</button>) vessel, allowing for a counter-current exchange mechanism.

The circulatory system of crayfish is not closed, like that of vertebrates. While the hemolymph does travel in vessels, it does not remain confined to them, but drains into open spaces called sinuses. From the gills, the hemolymph passes into the <button class='glossary-text'>pericardial sinus</button> (24) in the <button class='glossary-text'>cephalothorax</button>, where the heart (18) is located. Fluid flows into the box-shaped sac through three pairs of slits called <button class='glossary-text'>ostia</button>. From the heart, five arteries carry hemolymph toward the head, i.e., the antennary artery supplies the antennae and the ophthalmic artery supplies the eyes (Figure 2), whereas the <button class='glossary-text'>superior</button>, median, and <button class='glossary-text'>ventral</button> abdominal arteries, along with a sternal thoracic artery, supplies the <button class='glossary-text'>posterior</button> of the animal where they surround organs and other structures. From here, hemolymph drains into a large sternal sinus on the ventral side, which returns it to the gills.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Figure labeling the key internal features of the crayfish

pageData.subTitle: Nutrition and Digestion
pageData.text: Crayfish are omnivorous, feeding on both living and dead plants and animals. Food is grasped with the <button class='glossary-text'>chelipeds</button> and passed to the mouth. The mandibles hold the food while it is torn away by the maxillae. Once food has moved into the mouth, it travels via the esophagus to a two-chambered stomach (27). The first chamber is the cardiac chamber (Figure 2). Chitinous “teeth” in the cardiac chamber form the gastric mill, which grinds food into smaller particles. Large particles are prevented from exiting the cardiac stomach by a row of bristles. Most of the digestion occurs in the pyloric stomach, which is divided into two sections. The <button class='glossary-text'>dorsal</button> section leads directly into the intestine (19). Undigested food exits the stomach this way, passing through the intestine and out of the body via the anus (6). The two-lobed ventral section of the stomach is separated from the dorsal section by a row of paired denticles, which strain out large particles. Digestive enzymes are secreted in the double lobed hepatopancreas (sometimes called the digestive gland [10]) connected to each lobe of the ventral pyloric stomach. Gastric juices flow from the pyloric stomach into the hepatopancreas where further digestion and absorption occur.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Figure labeling the key internal features of the crayfish

pageData.subTitle: Waste Elimination
pageData.text: Crayfish have adapted to life in freshwater by being able to excrete hyposmotic (dilute) urine via glands commonly referred to as <button class='glossary-text'>green glands</button> (17) (Figure 2). The correct name of these is the antennal or maxillary glands, depending on where the gland empties. This varies with species, so the more generic term is used here. Blood surrounds the end sac and wastes and water are removed. The urine moves from the end sac via the excretory canal to the bladder, which can expand to hold urine. Urine exits the body via the excretory pore, either at the base of the antennae or just before the second maxillae.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Figure labeling the key internal features of the crayfish

pageData.question: What separates the ventral section of the stomach from the dorsal section?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The two-lobed ventral section of the stomach is separated from the dorsal section by a row of paired denticles, which strain out large particles.

pageData.question: Which structure(s) tear up food before it is moved to the mouth?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The mandibles hold the food while it is torn away by the maxillae.

Food is grasped with the chelipeds and passed to the mouth. Once food has moved into the mouth, it travels via the esophagus to a two-chambered stomach. The first chamber is the cardiac chamber. Most of the digestion occurs in the pyloric stomach, which is divided into two sections. The dorsal section leads directly into the intestine. Undigested food exits the stomach this way, passing through the intestine and out of the body via the anus. The two-lobed ventral section of the stomach is separated from the dorsal section by a row of paired denticles, which strain out large particles.

Food is grasped with the chelipeds and passed to the mouth. Once food has moved into the mouth, it travels via the esophagus to a two-chambered stomach. The first chamber is the cardiac chamber. pageData.subTitle: Senses and Nervous System
pageData.text: Crayfish are highly <button class='glossary-text'>cephalized</button>, with sensory organs concentrated in the head region. The first pair of antennae has <button class='glossary-text'>aesthetascs</button>, which are hairs used for smell and taste. Since they live on the bottom of waterways, frequent grooming is required to prevent fouling of the hairs from sediment. Aesthetascs are also present along the legs of crayfish.

Compound eyes sit atop eye stalks, allowing for a considerable range of vision. The eye has many long, cylindrical units called <button class='glossary-text'>ommatidium</button>, with each topped by a translucent cornea that is square. The cornea acts as a lens, which focuses light.

Behind the cornea is a long cone called the <button class='glossary-text'>crystalline cone</button>, which further focuses light onto the <button class='glossary-text'>retinula</button>. The eyes of most crayfish function differently from other arthropods. Pigment cells, which reduce the amount of light being received by the retinulas of arthropods such as bees, remain retracted in crayfish, allowing for the eye to gather more light and see better in low light conditions. The sides of the ommatidium are also reflective in crayfish, which further enhances incoming light.

Crayfish use organs, called <button class='glossary-text'>statocysts</button>, to determine orientation and maintain balance. The statocysts are a small sac-like organ containing <button class='glossary-text'>statoliths</button> (small grains of sand bound in secretions). Hairs line the bottom of the sac and trigger nerves based on the movement of sand in the sac.

The nervous system in crayfish is made up of a series of centralized ganglia (bundles of nerve cells forming a swelling on a nerve fiber) connected by nerve cords. The largest ganglion, sometimes referred to as the brain, is the <button class='glossary-text'>supraesophageal</button> or <button class='glossary-text'>cerebral ganglion</button>. Nerve cords from the brain run to the antennae, antennules, and eyestalks. Two nerve cords encircle the esophagus to join again in the <button class='glossary-text'>subesophageal ganglion</button> on the <button class='glossary-text'>ventral</button> side of the crayfish. From here, the central, ventral nerve cord runs the length of the body. <button class='glossary-text'>Lateral</button> nerves branch along each segment from ganglia along the ventral nerve cord.

pageData.subTitle: Reproduction and Development
pageData.text: Crayfish, like most other arthropods, have male and female individuals. The most obvious difference between the two, as mentioned previously, is the first two pairs of swimmerets. Females have a pair of ovaries located between the and the digestive gland. The oviduct leads from the ovary to the base of the third pair of walking legs (Figure 3). The testes in males are located in the same place as the ovaries, but the vas deferens runs to the fifth pair of walking legs, just before the copulatory swimmerets (13).

During copulation, the female is pinned on her <button class='glossary-text'>dorsal</button> surface under the male. The first pair of swimmerets of the male form a grove that, when lowered at a 45-degree angle, guides sperm into the seminal receptacle of the female (26), which is just behind the oviduct opening. The semen hardens into a plug and may remain there for some time until the female is ready to lay her eggs. The eggs flow out of the female’s oviduct and over the sperm plug where they are fertilized. The fertilized eggs move into a space formed by the female’s abdomen, which has been curled forward for this purpose. A single female can produce hundreds of offspring at one time.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Figure showing the longer copulatory swimmeretes in the male and the shorter subsequent swimmeretes in contrast to the female crayfish

pageData.text: The eggs formed are rich in yolk. Initial nuclear divisions are not accompanied by cellular division. A large number of nuclei are distributed around the periphery of the cell, where cell membranes form around them. This leaves a large central yolk surrounded by embryonic cells. The embryo continues to develop around the yolk periphery.

The female carries the embryos on her abdomen until hatching. Crayfish, unlike many of their marine relatives (e.g., shrimps, crabs, and lobsters), do not generally have a larval stage, but have direct development instead, i.e., they emerge from the eggs closely resembling adults, only much smaller. Many species remain with their mother for several weeks. Growth is rapid in the first year. Once a crayfish outgrows its , it will shed it in a process called . Immediately following molting the is soft, leaving the crayfish vulnerable to predators. Lifespan varies with species, but most mature in three to four months and live between three and eight years.

tableData.text: Front, synonymous with ventral in bipeds and cranial in quadrupeds
Back, synonymous with dorsal in bipeds and caudal in quadrupeds
Toward the right or left side
Near or toward the point of reference
Away from the point of reference, which is usually the attachment point
A significant distance below the surface
Divides the body into longitudinal left and right portions
Divides the body into equal left and right halves
Perpendicular to the long axis, produces cross-sections
Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

pageData.question: After fertilization, where do crayfish embryos develop?

options.text: on the rock where the female laid them

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The female crayfish carries the developing embryos on her abdomen until hatching.

pageData.question: During copulation, the female crayfish is pinned under the male on which of her surfaces?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The female crayfish is pinned on her dorsal surface (back) under the male.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: During copulation, the female is pinned on her back under the male. The first pair of swimmerets of the male form a grove that, when lowered at a 45-degree angle, guides sperm into the seminal receptacle of the female, which is just behind the oviduct opening. The semen hardens into a plug and may remain there for some time until the female is ready to lay her eggs. The eggs flow out of the female’s oviduct and over the sperm plug where they are fertilized. A large number of nuclei are distributed around the periphery of the cell, where cell membranes form around them. This leaves a large central yolk surrounded by embryonic cells. The embryo continues to develop around the yolk periphery.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, you will set up the dissection supplies and prepare the specimen for dissection. In activity 1, first examine the external anatomy. Then, determine the sex of the specimen. Next, remove a left cheliped and observe the gill. Then, remove the other chelipeds and the mouth appendages. Next, cut away the dorsal exoskeleton, then identify and remove the dorsal extensor muscles. Then, remove the left carapace and observe the gills. Then, cut into the cephalothorax and examine the internal organs. Finally, remove and examine the stomach.
pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, you will set up the dissection supplies and prepare the specimen for dissection. In activity 1, first examine the external anatomy. Then, determine the sex of the specimen. Next, remove a left cheliped and observe the gill. Then, remove the other chelipeds and the mouth appendages. Next, cut away the dorsal exoskeleton, then identify and remove the dorsal extensor muscles. Then, remove the left carapace and observe the gills. Then, cut into the cephalothorax and examine the internal organs. Finally, remove and examine the stomach.

content.text: Note: You can use your camera to help you see small structures. After you take a picture you can zoom in on the structures that you are interested in. This is also helpful when you are labeling the structures for your lab submission.

pageData.text: Reorder Information:Replacement supplies for the Crayfish Dissection investigation can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company, item number 580203.Call: 866-332-4478 to order.
This investigation requires safety goggles, disposable gloves, and a laboratory apron.

pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Follow the instructions for this activity closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE); safety goggles, gloves, and lab aprons must be worn when dissecting. Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing the dissection. Use proper hygiene practices before, during, and after the lab, including washing your hands before and after performing the dissection. Review pertinent portions of any Safety Data Sheets (SDS) before beginning the activity. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) is flammable. Keep away from open flame if using alcohol as disinfectant.
pageData.altText: flammable symbol

pageData.text: Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> causes mild skin irritation if suitable PPE is not worn. Avoid contact with skin and eyes. Do not ingest specimen, especially if you are or may become pregnant.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: Independent, certified laboratory analyses of specimens fixed in Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> have found that it is nontoxic and does not give off dangerous fumes. This means that, for safety purposes, use of Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> specimens does not require specialized ventilation. Carolina does recommend performing the dissection in a well-ventilated room with some active ventilation when working with any preserved specimens. For a home setting, this may include opening windows and turning on a ceiling fan. The safe nature of Carolina’s Perfect Solution® also means that in most localities there are no mandated disposal requirements.

Dissections require special attention to safety. Please follow these additional precautions:
  • Clean the counter or workspace thoroughly before and after the dissection, using isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant).
  • Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before and after the dissection.
  • Only perform the dissection on the dissecting tray. This will contain both the specimen and any excess fluids.
  • Spread the absorbent pad blue side down underneath the tray to capture any spilled fluid.
  • In general, scissors are used more frequently than the scalpel, especially when care must be taken not to cut too deeply into the specimen.
  • Scalpels are used infrequently in most dissection labs and require special handling and disposal.
  • Never cut toward your holding hand and fingers.
  • Cut in a downward motion using a steady, even pressure.
  • Always use a sharp blade.
  • Do not use a scalpel that is nicked, bent, or damaged.
  • Do not use a scalpel to cut through bone or heavy cartilage.
  • Never use a scalpel for anything other than dissection.

pageData.subTitle: Storage of Specimens
pageData.text: If it is necessary to store the specimen between work periods, you may choose to place it in the plastic storage bag with as much of the original solution as possible. Establishing an airtight seal is the best way to retain specimen integrity and prevent drying out of the specimen. First, squeeze as much air out of the specimen bag as possible before securing the opening with a rubber band, tape, or a binder clip. After closing the bag, the specimen can be stored in a larger, airtight box or bag at room temperature.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which part of a decapod’s body is covered by the carapace?

options.text: the dorsal side of the cephalothorax
the ventral side of the cephalothorax
the dorsal side of the abdomen
the ventral side of the abdomen

assestmentData.question: What is the exoskeleton of the crayfish mostly made up of?
Where in the digestive track of the crayfish does most digestion occur?
What is the primary function of the green glands of the crayfish?

options.text: to determine orientation and maintain balance

assestmentData.question: Which of these is referred to as the brain of a crayfish?
Which is the correct term for the gills that arise at the base of appendages?
Which crayfish appendage ends in a large claw?
Which of the following safety hazards is associated with isopropanol (rubbing alcohol), which will be used during this investigation?

options.text: It will stain skin or clothing.
It is extremely harmful to aquatic life.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is NOT accurate regarding proper scalpel use?

options.text: Cut toward your holding hand and fingers.
Cut in a downward motion using a steady, even pressure.
Use a scalpel that does not have any nicks or is free from damage.
Only use the scalpel for dissection purposes.

assestmentData.question: Which of these is the process by which a crayfish sheds its old exoskeleton?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Review the dissection instructions (while referring to the dissection mat).
Print out the dissection procedure to avoid getting fluid from the specimen on your computer or mobile device.
Clean the work area.
Put on your PPE: safety glasses, gloves, and lab apron, and keep them on during dissection and cleanup.
Lay the pad on the work area with the blue, absorbent side facing down.
Lay out all dissecting instruments on the pad.
Place the dissecting tray in the middle of the pad to absorb any fluid that might spill onto the work area.
Position the dissection mat so it is easy to read. In the activity, structures that are shown on the dissection mat are indicated by numbers in parentheses.

In Activity 1, you will observe the external anatomy of the crayfish including determining the sex and observing the limbs and gills. You will then cut into the <button class='glossary-text'>exoskeleton</button> to observe musculature and the internal organs.
Obtain a dissecting tray and a set of dissecting instruments.
Place the crayfish in the dissecting tray.
Use <button class='resource-text'>Figure 1</button> to identify the parts of the external anatomy.

Examine the fourth pleopod. Notice that it attaches to the abdomen (1) by a single stalk and ends in two arms. In addition, note that the uropod (30) is similar in structure, although it is different in appearance.

Determine the sex of your crayfish by observing the first two pairs of pleopods. In the male, these sets of appendages are hard and conspicuous. In females, the first pair is tiny and the other pairs are longer. Use <button class='resource-text'>Figure 3</button> to assist you. Take a photograph of the <button class='glossary-text'>ventral</button> surface of your crayfish.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Remove the crayfish’s left <button class='glossary-text'>cheliped</button> (9) (the first walking leg) by grasping the appendage at its base with forceps, bending it sharply to the left and right, and lifting up. If you are successful in removing the complete cheliped, you will find a feathery structure attached to its base; this is a gill (15). Take a photograph. If you are not successful in removing a gill here, you will be able to photograph others in Activity 1B.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Remove the other walking legs (31) (using the same technique as in Step 6) from the left side.

Remove the mouth appendages on the crayfish’s left side by lifting each one individually, grasping the base with forceps, and pulling firmly. Do not remove the mandible (20), but instead observe it in place.

You should find that the second and third maxillipeds (23) have gills attached. Between the first maxilla (22) and the mandible is a thin, flat structure that curves tightly against the mandible. This is the metastoma, which is a sense organ and not a true appendage.

typeBefore.text: Use scissors to make the incisions in the following steps. Make sure that you only cut through the <button class='glossary-text'>exoskeleton</button>, which is made of hard chitin, to avoid damaging the soft internal tissues and organs.

pageData.text: Bend the telson (29) down and make an incision along the joint between the <button class='glossary-text'>posterior</button> abdominal segments. Cut through the exoskeleton (11) only. Avoid damaging the soft inner tissues.

Make incisions as indicated by the dotted lines in Figure 4. Remove the <button class='glossary-text'>dorsal</button> exoskeleton by lifting it slightly with forceps and cutting it free from the soft tissues that cling to it. Take a picture of the ventral and dorsal sides of your crayfish.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.desc: Diagram showing locations of the cuts to be performed
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Diagram showing locations of the cuts to be performed

pageData.text: Identify the abdominal extensors (2) and flexors (3) on the dorsal side. Photograph the extensor muscles before removing them to reveal the flexors and the intestine. To remove the extensor muscles, gently cut along the same lines used to remove the <button class='glossary-text'>carapace</button>. Make another shallow cut down the mid-line of the crayfish, and use the forceps to gently lift out each set of extensor muscles. Take a picture of the intestine and the flexor muscles.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Remove the carapace (7) from the left side of the crayfish by cutting down from point A of Figure 4 to the ventral-<button class='glossary-text'>anterior</button> edge of the carapace and freeing it from the tissue, which connects the carapace to the body or body wall. This exposes the branchial chamber, a space between the body wall and the carapace that contains the gills. Take a photograph that shows the branchial chamber and gills.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Some gills would not have been removed with the walking legs. Remove these gills and the body wall behind them.
Remove the left ventral wall of the <button class='glossary-text'>cephalothorax</button> (8) by making an incision from the ventral posterior of the cephalothorax to just anterior of the mouth.

Use <button class='resource-text'>Figure 2</button> to help you identify the heart (18) and gonad (16). You may need to remove a portion of the hepatopancreas (10), and some muscles. Try to locate the sternal artery. Take a photograph of these structures.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: After studying the internal anatomy of the crayfish, remove the stomach (27), cut through its ventral surface, and spread it open.

Examine the stomach interior to locate the three sets of beak-like teeth, which chew the food. Posterior to the teeth are numerous bristles. These bristles prevent large food particles from passing into the intestine (19).

text: Dispose of any excess fluids down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run for about 30 seconds to dilute the fluids.
Place the specimen in its storage bag and seal tightly. If you are finished working with your specimen, put the bag into an opaque trash bag for disposal in the household garbage bin.
Rinse and carefully air dry the dissection tools, and return the materials to your equipment kit.

Sanitize the workspace with isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant) and paper towels. If this is insufficient for removing grease during cleanup, use soap and water, followed by more alcohol/disinfectant.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.altText: completion

tableData.text: Also includes spiders, centipedes, and insects
Also includes krill and pill bugs
Also includes shrimp, lobster, and crabs

pageData.content: Figure 1. External anatomy of a crayfish
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Figure labeling key external features of the crayfish

pageData.content: Figure 2. Internal anatomy of a crayfish
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Figure labeling the key internal features of the crayfish
Figure 3: Figure showing the longer copulatory swimmeretes in the male and the shorter subsequent swimmeretes in contrast to the female crayfish

tableData.text: Front, synonymous with ventral in bipeds and cranial in quadrupeds
Back, synonymous with dorsal in bipeds and caudal in quadrupeds
Toward the right or left side
Near or toward the point of reference
Away from the point of reference, which is usually the attachment point
A significant distance below the surface
Divides the body into longitudinal left and right portions
Divides the body into equal left and right halves
Perpendicular to the long axis, produces cross-sections
Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, you will set up the dissection supplies and prepare the specimen for dissection. In activity 1, first examine the external anatomy. Then, determine the sex of the specimen. Next, remove a left cheliped and observe the gill. Then, remove the other chelipeds and the mouth appendages. Next, cut away the dorsal exoskeleton, then identify and remove the dorsal extensor muscles. Then, remove the left carapace and observe the gills. Then, cut into the cephalothorax and examine the internal organs. Finally, remove and examine the stomach.
Figure 4: Diagram showing locations of the cuts to be performed

data.title: Aesthetasc
data.content: A hair used for smell and taste

data.title: Afferent
data.content: Conducting inward

data.title: Anterior
data.content: Front, synonymous with ventral in bipeds and cranial quadrupeds

data.title: Arthrobranch
data.content: A gill located at the articular membrane between the coxa and the body wall

data.title: Benthic
data.content: Describes flora or fauna found on the bottom of a deep body of water

data.title: Branchiostegite
data.content: The extended pleural part of the carapace forming one wall of the gill chamber in crustaceans

data.title: Carapace
data.content: The hard upper shell covering the dorsal side of the cephalothorax

data.title: Caudal
data.content: Toward the tail

data.title: Cephalized
data.content: Having sensory organs concentrated in the head region

data.title: Cephalothorax
data.content: A fused head and thorax

data.title: Cerebral ganglion
data.content: One of a pair of ganglia situated in the head or anterior part of the body; also known as a supraesophageal ganglion

data.title: Cheliped
data.content: Either of two legs which each carry a large claw

data.title: Coxae
data.content: The segment of the leg closest to the body; singular, coxa

data.title: Cranial
data.content: Toward the head

data.title: Crystalline cone
data.content: The structure that focuses light onto the retinula

data.title: Deep
data.content: A significant distance below the surface

data.title: Distal
data.content: Away from the point of reference, which is usually the attachment point

data.title: Dorsal
data.content: Toward the back

data.title: Efferent
data.content: Conducting outward

data.title: Exoskeleton
data.content: A rigid external covering for the body in some invertebrate animals providing both support and protection

data.title: Frontal plane
data.content: The plane that divides the body into dorsal and ventral positions

data.title: Gill bailer
data.content: A thin, leaf-like appendage that helps to pull water out of the gill chamber; also called a scaphognathite

data.title: Green gland
data.content: A gland by which crayfish excrete urine

data.title: Inferior
data.content: Below, toward the feet

data.title: Lateral
data.content: Toward the right or left side

data.title: Medial
data.content: Toward the midline

data.title: Midsagittal plane
data.content: The plane that divides the body into equal left and right halves

data.title: Molting
data.content: The process of shedding the exoskeleton to make way for a new growth

data.title: Ommatidium
data.content: A cylindrical unit of the compound eye of insects and other arthropods; plural, ommatidia

data.title: Ostia
data.content: The small openings that can be found on either side of the body through which fluid can flow; singular, ostium

data.title: Pericardial sinus
data.content: A sac or cavity located in the upper thorax

data.title: Pleurobranch
data.content: A gill arising from the side of the thorax

data.title: Podobranch
data.content: A gill attached to the base of a thoracic limb

data.title: Posterior
data.content: Back, synonymous with dorsal in bipeds and caudal quadrupeds

data.title: Proximal
data.content: Near or toward the point of reference

data.title: Retinula
data.content: The neural receptor of a single facet of an arthropod compound eye

data.title: Rostral
data.content: Toward the nose or mouth

data.title: Rostrum
data.content: A beak-like projection or anterior prolongation of the head of an insect, crustacean, or cetacean

data.title: Sagittal plane
data.content: The plane that divides the body into longitudinal left and right portions

data.title: Scaphognathite
data.content: See "gill bailer"

data.title: Segmentation
data.content: The characteristic in which a body is composed of repeated units (segments)

data.title: Setae
data.content: The stiff hairs found on the coxae which filter water before it reaches the gills; singular, seta

data.title: Statocyst
data.content: A small, sac-like organ used to determine orientation and maintain balance

data.title: Statolith
data.content: A small grain of sand bound in secretions and found in statocysts

data.title: Subseophageal ganglion
data.content: A ganglion used to control the mouthparts, salivary glands and neck muscles

data.title: Superficial
data.content: Toward or along the surface

data.title: Superior
data.content: Above, toward the head

data.title: Supraesophageal ganglion
data.content: See "cerebral ganglion"

data.title: Transverse plane
data.content: The body plane perpendicular to the long axis; cutting along this plane produces cross-sections

data.title: Ventral
data.content: Toward the belly or abdomen
